comment.brief: An extended navigation interface implemented by full navigation behaviors.
comment.full:
An extended navigation interface implemented by full navigation behaviors.

This API is subject to significant changes in coming versions. Though previously not marked as experimental, there is a need to consolidate and group some of the events and states to remain maintainable, fix some defects, and add some required features.

comment.brief:
When implemented by a `Node`, it indicates that the node provides data for its children.
@hide
comment.full:
When implemented by a `Node`, it indicates that the node provides data for its children.
@hide

comment.brief: A minimal interface implemented by simple navigation behaviors and controls.
comment.full: A minimal interface implemented by simple navigation behaviors and controls.

comment.brief: Interface for objects that can have a script engine representation
comment.full: Interface for objects that can have a script engine representation

syntax.uno: public abstract partial class NavigationControl : Fuse.Controls.Panel, Fuse.Navigation.INavigation, Fuse.ISubtreeDataProvider, Fuse.Navigation.IBaseNavigation {}

comment.brief:
A standard page navigation system. This provides standard transitions, user interaction and
appropriate page handling for a basic linear navigation.
comment.full:
A standard page navigation system. This provides standard transitions, user interaction and
appropriate page handling for a basic linear navigation.

comment.brief: The currently active visual of the navigation.
comment.full: The currently active visual of the navigation.

comment.brief: Whether or not input to block input to the pages during navigation.
comment.full:
Whether or not input to block input to the pages during navigation.

The default is `WhileNavigating`: the pages will not get any pointer input during navigation.

comment.brief: Specifies whether this control participates in routing (is it a router outlet).
comment.full:
Specifies whether this control participates in routing (is it a router outlet).

The default is "true".

comment.brief: Pages is a stack of pages that controls the local history for a NavigationControl.
comment.full:
Pages is a stack of pages that controls the local history for a NavigationControl.

It should be bound to a JavaScript observable array. The highest index page will always be the active page for the control. As pages are added/removed from this array the navigation state will change.

The items in the array are objects, either explicitly created or via the Model feature. They should contain the the `$path` property which specifies the path to use. The object itself will be added to the data context for the page, allowing lookups from within the object.

The `$navigationRequest` property may be used to fine-tune how transitions to the pages performed. Without this property the control will infer the type of transition based on how the array has been modified. The properties are a subset of those offered by `modifyPath`:

    - `transition`: Either `Bypass` or `Transition`
    - `style`: The style of the operation, which can be used as a matching criteria in transitions.
    - `operation`: `Pop`, `Replace`, `Push` or `Goto`

comment.brief:
Specifies what transitions should be used for page navigation. If you wish to create your own
transitions set to `None` and add your own to the pages.
comment.full:
Specifies what transitions should be used for page navigation. If you wish to create your own
transitions set to `None` and add your own to the pages.

When using custom transitions be sure to add a @ReleasePage action. This instructs the `Navigator` on when it can reuse, discard, or add the page to its cache.

comment.brief:
The background color of the panel.
This property is a shortcut for setting the `Background` property to a `SolidColor` brush. Supports being set using a `float4` notation, or hexadecimal values(f.ex `#FF00AA`)
comment.full:
The background color of the panel.
This property is a shortcut for setting the `Background` property to a `SolidColor` brush. Supports being set using a `float4` notation, or hexadecimal values(f.ex `#FF00AA`)

For more information on what notations Color supports, check out [this subpage](articles:ux-markup/literals#colors).

comment.brief: Defers the freezing of the panel until the children are no longer busy.
comment.full:
Defers the freezing of the panel until the children are no longer busy.

When `None` (the default), the freezing will happen the same frame `IsFrozen` is set to `true`. Otherwise the panel will wait for all children to clear the busy status of this type before doing the freezing.

comment.brief:
When `true` the panel is in a frozen state. This means:
    - layout of the children is blocked
    - child invalidation does not invalidate this panel
    - the visual drawing is captured once and used for all future drawing
comment.full:
When `true` the panel is in a frozen state. This means:
    - layout of the children is blocked
    - child invalidation does not invalidate this panel
    - the visual drawing is captured once and used for all future drawing

`IsFrozen` allows improving performance in some use-cases, such as Navigation, where the children may not be completely stable. This can result from such things as data bindings resolving, deferred items resolving, and images loading. Note that it will also block all intentional animation as well until unfrozen.

Warning: Trigger timing is not blocked at the moment, and animations will jump over the lost time when unfrozen again.

comment.brief: The layout that will be applied to the children.
comment.full:
The layout that will be applied to the children.

This property is rarely set directly. Instead, you use a subclass of @LayoutControl
that already sets this property, such as a @Panel class.

## Available Panel classes

[subclass Fuse.Controls.Panel]

## Available Layout classes

[subclass Fuse.Layouts.Layout]

comment.brief: The brush that will used to paint the background of this control.
comment.full:
The brush that will used to paint the background of this control.

To set a solid color as background, consider using the @Color property instead.

This property is automatically set if you put a brush inside the control, e.g.

<Panel>
    <LinearGradient>
        <GradientStop Offset="0" Color="Black" />
        <GradientStop Offset="0" Color="Black" />
    </LinearGradient>
</Panel>

comment.brief: The @Alignment of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The @Alignment of the `Element`.

Used to position an `Element` within its available space if the `Element` doesn't simply fill that space.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: A point within the element to treat as its "epicenter".
comment.full:
A point within the element to treat as its "epicenter".

The `Anchor` partially specifies how an element is aligned within it's parent. Properties like `Alignment`
and `X`, `Y` define a location in the parent to place the child, and `Anchor` specifies what child point is
aligned there.

For example, `<Panel X="50" Y="100" Anchor="25%,25%">` positions the middle of the top-left quarter (25%,25%) of the panel at point 50,100 in the parent.

`Alignment` implies a coordinate and anchor point, for example `<Panel Alignment="BottomRight">` is that same as `<Panel X="100%" Y="100%" Anchor="100%,100%">`. You can use `alignment` and override the anchor, for examlpe `<Panel Alignment="BottomRight" Anchor="50%,50%">` centers the panel at the bottom right point of the parent.

comment.brief: The aspect ratio that an element must fulfill in layout.
comment.full:
The aspect ratio that an element must fulfill in layout.

This is the X:Y ratio. `2` is twice as wide as tall and `0.5` is half as wide as tall.

comment.brief: Determines how the aspect ratio is maintained in a situation when it violates the min or max sizing constraints.
comment.full: Determines how the aspect ratio is maintained in a situation when it violates the min or max sizing constraints.

comment.brief: The manner in which the size and position of the element is calculated.
comment.full: The manner in which the size and position of the element is calculated.

comment.brief: How the element's visuals are cached while drawing.
comment.full:
How the element's visuals are cached while drawing.

You generally don't need to modify this as the default uses a heuristical approach to determine what it should and should not cache. Modifying this incorrectly could result in worse performance.

comment.brief: Clips the child elements to the bounds of this element visually.
comment.full: Clips the child elements to the bounds of this element visually.

comment.brief: The height of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The height of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have a specific height on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: Specifies how hit tests should be performed on this element.
comment.full: Specifies how hit tests should be performed on this element.

comment.brief: The height limit for an element using `BoxSizing="Limit"`.
comment.full: The height limit for an element using `BoxSizing="Limit"`.

comment.brief: The width limit for an element using `BoxSizing="Limit"`.
comment.full: The width limit for an element using `BoxSizing="Limit"`.

comment.brief: The margin of the `Element` in points.
comment.full:
The margin of the `Element` in points.

`Margin` controls the distance from the edges of an element to the corresponding edges of its container.

`Margin` is made up of 4 values; one for each edge of the element. In order, they are left, top, right, and bottom. In UX, they are specified as a comma-separated list:

    <Panel Margin="10,20,30,40" />

They can also be specified in a shortened form:

    <Panel Margin="10" /> <!-- is expanded to "10,10,10,10" -->
    <Panel Margin="10,20" /> <!-- is expanded to "10,20,10,20" -->

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The maximum height of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The maximum height of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have no greater than the given height on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The maximum width of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The maximum width of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have no greater than the given width on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The minimum height of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The minimum height of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have at least the given height on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The minimum width of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The minimum width of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have at least the given width on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: Offets the position of the element after all other layout has been applied.
comment.full:
Offets the position of the element after all other layout has been applied.

For example, `<StackPanel Alignment="TopCenter" Offset="0,10">` would position the `StackPanel` 10 points down from the top its parent, after all other layout has been applied (@Margin, @Padding, etc).

comment.brief: The opacity of the element.
comment.full:
The opacity of the element.

When `0`, the element will be completely transparent, yet will still be considered for hit testing (it and it's children are still actually part of the UI). To make an element invisble without hit testing set `Visibility="Hidden"`

comment.brief: The padding of the `Element` in points.
comment.full:
The padding of the `Element` in points.

`Padding` controls the distance from the edges of an element to the edges of the elements inside it. It's very similar to @Margin, except that it works "inwards".

`Padding` is made up of 4 values; one for each edge of the element. In order, they are left, top, right, and bottom. In UX, they are specified as a comma-separated list:

    <Panel Padding="10,20,30,40" />

They can also be specified in a shortened form:

    <Panel Padding="10" /> <!-- is expanded to "10,10,10,10" -->
    <Panel Padding="10,20" /> <!-- is expanded to "10,20,10,20" -->

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The combined `X` and `Y` position of the element.
comment.full:
The combined `X` and `Y` position of the element.

If using this property avoid using `X` or `Y` properties, as this is an combined alias for those properties. Choose the property that works easier for your desired bindined, expressions and animations.

comment.brief: The combined `Width` and `Height` of the element.
comment.full:
The combined `Width` and `Height` of the element.

If using this property avoid using `Width` or `Height` as this is a combined alias for those properties. Choose the property that works easier for your desired binding, expressions and animations.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: Specifies the origin of transformation used by transformation behaviors and animators such as @Move, @Scale, @Rotation, @Scaling, etc.
comment.full:
Specifies the origin of transformation used by transformation behaviors and animators such as @Move, @Scale, @Rotation, @Scaling, etc.

The possible values are:

 * `Center` (default) Transforms originate at the center of the element.
 * `TopLeft` Transforms originate at the top left corner of the element.
 * `Anchor` Transforms originate around the point specified by the @Element.Anchor property.
 * `HorizontalBoxCenter` Simulates the effect of the element being the front-facing side of a cube in 3D space, using the width of the element for determining the depth of the cube. Without the element being in a @Viewport this will have no illusion of depth, effectively rendering it useless.
 * `VerticalBoxCenter` Like `HorizontalBoxCenter` except it uses the height of the element for determining depth.

comment.brief: The @Visibility of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The @Visibility of the `Element`.

Used to determine if the `Element` is displayed on screen, and can also affect its layout.

Possible values:
- `Visible` - The element is displayed on-screen as usual.
- `Hidden` - The element will not be displayed on-screen, but will still participate in and affect layout normally.
- `Collapsed` - The element will not be displayed on-screen or participate in layout.

## Example

In the following example, only two of the rectangles are visible. The second Rectangle is collapsed,
so it's not taking up any space at all. The third Rectangle is hidden, so it takes up space, but is not
visible. The last Rectangle has no Visibility set, so it defaults to being visible as usual.

    <StackPanel>
        <Rectangle Visibility="Visible" Color="Red" Height="50"/>
        <Rectangle Visibility="Collapsed" Color="Green" Height="50"/>
        <Rectangle Visibility="Hidden" Color="Blue" Height="50"/>
        <Rectangle Color="Yellow" Height="50"/>
    </StackPanel>

comment.brief: The width of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The width of the `Element`.

Used to ensure an element will have a specific width on-screen.

See @Layout for more details.

comment.brief: The `X` location of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The `X` location of the `Element`.

This implies `Alignment=TopLeft`, thus by default measures from the top left corner of the parent.

comment.brief: The `Y` location of the `Element`.
comment.full:
The `Y` location of the `Element`.

This implies `Alignment=TopLeft`, thus by default measures from the top left corner of the parent.

comment.brief:
The children of the visual.
All nodes placed inside the visual in UX markup are assigned to this list.
The order of @Visuals this list determines the order of layout. The Z-order
of the children is by default equal to this order, but can be manipulated
separately using methods like @BringToFront and @SendToBack.
comment.full:
The children of the visual.
All nodes placed inside the visual in UX markup are assigned to this list.
The order of @Visuals this list determines the order of layout. The Z-order
of the children is by default equal to this order, but can be manipulated
separately using methods like @BringToFront and @SendToBack.

comment.brief:
Whether this node is currently interactable.
Disabled visuals do not receive input focus. However, they can still
be visible and block hit test for underlaying objects.
comment.full:
Whether this node is currently interactable.
Disabled visuals do not receive input focus. However, they can still
be visible and block hit test for underlaying objects.

You can use the @WhileEnabled and @WhileDisabled triggers to specify different styling for
a visual while enabled/disabled.

comment.brief: The layer this visual belongs to in the @Parent container.
comment.full: The layer this visual belongs to in the @Parent container.

comment.brief: Describes how this visual participates in layout.
comment.full: Describes how this visual participates in layout.

comment.brief: The parameter data for this visual, encoded as JSON, provided by a router if this visual represents a navigation page.
The list of resources defined at this node.
comment.full: The list of resources defined at this node.

comment.brief: Whether to snap the result of layout of this visual to physical device pixels.
comment.full: Whether to snap the result of layout of this visual to physical device pixels.

comment.brief: List of templates that will be used to populate this Visual.
comment.full:
List of templates that will be used to populate this Visual.

This list allows you to place nodes with a `ux:Template="key"` attribute inside a @Visual in UX Markup,
where `key` is the match key to be used when selecting a template.

This list has many use cases. For example, when populating a view with data, the correct template can be
picked based on a field    in the data source:

    <StackPanel Items="{items}" MatchKey="type">
        <SmallProfile ux:Template="small_profile" />
        <BigProfile ux:Template="big_profile" />
    </StackPanel>

The name of the template can also have a special significance in certain contexts, for example when dealing
with native control wrappers:

    <Control ux:Class="MySlider">
        <MyWrappers.iOS.Slider ux:Template="iOSAppearance" />
        <MyWrappers.Android.Slider ux:Template="AndroidAppearance" />
        <MyWrappers.Graphics.Slider ux:Template="GraphicsAppearance" />
    </Control>

comment.brief: Specifies a Z-Offset, visuals with higher values are in front of other visuals.
comment.full:
Specifies a Z-Offset, visuals with higher values are in front of other visuals.

The default value is `0`. Visuals with the same ZOffset are sorted by their natural
Z-Order according to their position in the `Children`-collection of the parent.
`BringToFront` and `SendToBack` can be used to modify the natural Z-Order.

`Layer` takes priority. Visuals in different layers are sorted separately.

comment.brief: The list of bindings belonging to this node.
comment.full: The list of bindings belonging to this node.

comment.brief:
Run-time name of the node.
This property is automatically set using the ux:Name attribute.
comment.full:
Run-time name of the node.
This property is automatically set using the ux:Name attribute.

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: @hide
comment.full: @hide

comment.brief: Raised when the element receives a new position and size by the layout engine.
Go to the desired page. This may reuse the existing page if it is compatible.
comment.full:
Go to the desired page. This may reuse the existing page if it is compatible.

This is not a router method. It is a local change to the navigation control. If used in a router it will modify the current path and not alter the history.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: the name of the path to use

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.description: an optional parameter for the page

comment.brief: Goto the desired page and modify the local history.
comment.full:
Goto the desired page and modify the local history.

The properties here match the same named properties of `router.modify`

The navigationSpec is a JavaScript object that specifies all the properties for the modification,
for example:

    nav.modifyPath({
        how: "Goto",
        path: [ "one", {} ],
        transition: "Bypass",
    })

This gotos to the "one" page without a transition.

The options are:
    - `how`: One of:
        - `Goto`: Clears the current route stack, like `goto()`
        - `Push`: Pushes a new path onto the route stack, like `push()`
        - `Replace`: Replaces the current item on the route stack wtih a new path
        - `GoBack`: Returns to the previous page in the local history (or an explictily provided one)
    - `path`: An array specifying the path and parameter parts in pairs, or an object page specification. The result must be a single path component as it affects only the local NavigationControl.
    - `transition`: An optional argument:
        - `Transition`: A normal animated transition. This is the default.
        - `Bypass`: A bypass transtiion that skips animation.
    - `style`: The style of the operation, which can be used as a matching criteria in transitions.

comment.brief: Go to the desired page without using a transition (bypass mode). This may reuse the existing page if it is compatible.
comment.full:
Go to the desired page without using a transition (bypass mode). This may reuse the existing page if it is compatible.

This is not a router method. It is a local change to the navigation control. If used in a router it will modify the current path and not alter the history.

parameters.name: path
parameters.description: the name of the path to use

parameters.name: parameter
parameters.description: an optional parameter for the page

comment.brief:
Requests that this visual be brought into the visible are of the screen. Typically a containing
`ScrollView` will scroll to ensure it is visible.
comment.full:
Requests that this visual be brought into the visible are of the screen. Typically a containing
`ScrollView` will scroll to ensure it is visible.

comment.brief: Registers a function to be called whenever the routing parameter is changed.
comment.full:
Registers a function to be called whenever the routing parameter is changed.

This is typically used in conjunction with the @Router type that allows parameters to be
specified in the @Router.goto and @Router.push operations.

## Example

This method is deprecated - use the following pattern instead:

    <Panel ux:Name="channelView">
        <JavaScript>
            channelView.Parameter.onValueChanged(module, function(param) {
                // lookup channel with id "param"
            })
        </JavaScript>

parameters.name: callback
parameters.description: The script method to call when the parameter changes. This is guaranted to becalled at least once at registration time; you don't need to lookup the parameter another way.

comment.brief: See @Navigation.CanGoBack
comment.full: See @Navigation.CanGoBack

comment.brief: See @Navigation.CanGoForward
comment.full: See @Navigation.CanGoForward

comment.brief: See @Navigation.ActivePage
comment.full: See @Navigation.ActivePage

comment.brief: See @Navigation.PageCount
comment.full: See @Navigation.PageCount

comment.brief: See @Navigation.PageProgress
comment.full: See @Navigation.PageProgress

comment.brief: See @INavigation.State
comment.full: See @INavigation.State

comment.brief: The anchor of element.
comment.full:
The anchor of element.

Only available after layout of the element is complete.

comment.brief: The position of the element, the position of its top-left corner to the top-left corner in the parent.
comment.full:
The position of the element, the position of its top-left corner to the top-left corner in the parent.

Only available after layout of the element is complete.

comment.brief: The size of the element.
comment.full:
The size of the element.

This is the resulting size after layout and may not match the requested `Width`, `Height`, or other size properties. Those are all interpreted to produce this resulting size.

Only available after layout of the element is complete.

comment.brief: Returns the origin of this Visual in the viewport (world) space.
comment.full:
Returns the origin of this Visual in the viewport (world) space.

This is used in layout to calculate pixel snapping.

comment.brief: The number of child nodes of this visual.
comment.full: The number of child nodes of this visual.

comment.brief: Whether this visual has any visual child nodes.
comment.full: Whether this visual has any visual child nodes.

comment.brief:
Whether this node is in an enabled context.
The context is disabled if one of the ancestor nodes have @IsEnabled set to `false`.
comment.full:
Whether this node is in an enabled context.
The context is disabled if one of the ancestor nodes have @IsEnabled set to `false`.

You can use the @WhileContextEnabled and @WhileContextDisabled triggers to specify different
styling for    a visual while the context is enabled or disabled.

comment.brief: Returns whether this visual is visible without concern for whether an ancestor visual is hidden or collapsed.
comment.full: Returns whether this visual is visible without concern for whether an ancestor visual is hidden or collapsed.

comment.brief:
Returns whether this visual is currently visible.
Will return false if any of the ancestor visuals are hidden or collapsed.
This property can *not* be used to check whether a visual is hidden because it is occluded by
another visual, or is outside the view but otherwise visible.
comment.full:
Returns whether this visual is currently visible.
Will return false if any of the ancestor visuals are hidden or collapsed.
This property can *not* be used to check whether a visual is hidden because it is occluded by
another visual, or is outside the view but otherwise visible.

comment.brief: The number of child visuals of this visual.
comment.full: The number of child visuals of this visual.

comment.brief:
The context parent is the semantic parent of this node. It is where non-UI structure should
be resolved, like looking for the DataContext, a Navigation, or other semantic item.
comment.full:
The context parent is the semantic parent of this node. It is where non-UI structure should
be resolved, like looking for the DataContext, a Navigation, or other semantic item.

comment.brief:
Whether rooting for this node is completed.
Returns false if unrooting has started.
comment.full:
Whether rooting for this node is completed.
Returns false if unrooting has started.

comment.brief:
Whether rooting of this node has started.
Note that even if this property returns true, rooting may not yet be
completed for the node. See also @IsRootingCompleted.
comment.full:
Whether rooting of this node has started.
Note that even if this property returns true, rooting may not yet be
completed for the node. See also @IsRootingCompleted.

comment.brief: The parent @Visual of this node. Will return null if the node is not rooted.
comment.full: The parent @Visual of this node. Will return null if the node is not rooted.

comment.brief: A linked list holding data for extrinsic properties.
comment.full: A linked list holding data for extrinsic properties.

comment.brief:
How the stnadard triggers are implemented will differ depending on the navigation type
being used.
comment.full:
How the stnadard triggers are implemented will differ depending on the navigation type
being used.

parameters.name: c
parameters.description: the element targeted by the trigger (don't add them here, just create them)

parameters.name: pd
parameters.description: where to store the created triggers

comment.brief: See @Navigation.GetPage
comment.full: See @Navigation.GetPage

comment.brief: See @INavigation.GetPageState
comment.full: See @INavigation.GetPageState

comment.brief: See @Navigation.GoBack
comment.full: See @Navigation.GoBack

comment.brief: See @Navigation.GoForward
comment.full: See @Navigation.GoForward

comment.brief: See @Navigation.Goto
comment.full: See @Navigation.Goto

comment.brief: See @Navigation.Toggle
comment.full: See @Navigation.Toggle

comment.brief: Called when the interaction for the control should be setup.
comment.full: Called when the interaction for the control should be setup.

comment.brief:
The provided LayoutParams is guaranteed to have a defined size that should be used
to layout the padding box.
comment.full:
The provided LayoutParams is guaranteed to have a defined size that should be used
to layout the padding box.

NOTE: ActualSize and ActualPosition will not be updated at this time.

parameters.name: cancelled
parameters.description: will be called if the interaction is cancelled

comment.brief: Begins removing a given node, playing all @RemovedAnimations before actual removal.
comment.full: Begins removing a given node, playing all @RemovedAnimations before actual removal.

comment.brief: Begins removing a given visual, playing all @RemovedAnimations before actual removal.
comment.full: Begins removing a given visual, playing all @RemovedAnimations before actual removal.

comment.brief:
Brings the given child to the front of the Z-order.
In UX markup, use the @BringToFront trigger action instead.
comment.full:
Brings the given child to the front of the Z-order.
In UX markup, use the @BringToFront trigger action instead.

comment.brief: Returns the first child node of the given type.
comment.full:
Returns the first child node of the given type.

To get the very first child node (of any type), use `FirstChild<Node>()`.

comment.brief: Returns the visual child with the given index.
comment.full:
Returns the visual child with the given index.

For performance reasons, avoid using this function.

comment.brief: Get the Visual for a given z-order
comment.full:
Get the Visual for a given z-order

This method might have a surprisingly high performance impact; avoid calling it in
performance sensitive code-paths.

comment.brief: Inserts a child node after the given sibling node.
comment.full:
Inserts a child node after the given sibling node.

For performance reasons, this entrypoint is recommended over using `InsertAt`.

To insert at the beginning of the list, use `null` as the first argument.

comment.brief:
Indicates that this element requires a new layout as some layout parameters or content
have changed.
comment.full:
Indicates that this element requires a new layout as some layout parameters or content
have changed.

This does not directly change any sizes or invalidate any cached values. The actual changes done
during a call to `ArrangeMarginBox` must invalidate those as appropriate.

comment.brief: Indicates the `RenderBounds` have changed and need to be recalculated.
comment.full:
Indicates the `RenderBounds` have changed and need to be recalculated.

This implies `InvalidateVisual`.

comment.brief:
Indicates the visual for this node has changed. This allows the root-level node to know
that it must draw, and any caching that it must invalidate the cache for this node.
comment.full:
Indicates the visual for this node has changed. This allows the root-level node to know
that it must draw, and any caching that it must invalidate the cache for this node.

comment.brief:
Indicates the composition of the visual has changed, but that the visual drawing itself is
still valid (for example a position change).
comment.full:
Indicates the composition of the visual has changed, but that the visual drawing itself is
still valid (for example a position change).

returns.text: Yes if the child influences the results of ArrangeMarginBox (size or layout of this node),No if it cannot, and Maybe otherwise (in cases of stretching)

comment.brief: Returns the last child node of the given type.
comment.full:
Returns the last child node of the given type.

To get the very last child node (of any type), use `LastChild<Node>()`.

comment.brief: Converts a coordinate from the local space into the parent space.
comment.full: Converts a coordinate from the local space into the parent space.

comment.brief: Removes all children of the given type.
comment.full:
Removes all children of the given type.

To remove all children (of all types), use `RemoveAllChildren<Node>()`.

comment.brief:
Sends the given child to the back of the Z-order.
In UX markup, use the @SendToBack trigger action instead.
comment.full:
Sends the given child to the back of the Z-order.
In UX markup, use the @SendToBack trigger action instead.

comment.brief: Converts a coordinate from the parent space into the local space.
comment.full: Converts a coordinate from the parent space into the local space.

returns.text: true if the result is defined, false is the calculation could not be performed.

parameters.name: result
parameters.description: The result will be stored here. It is undefined if the return is `false`

comment.brief:
Finds the first node with a given name that satisfies the given acceptor.
The serach algorithm works as follows: Nodes in the subtree are matched first, then
it matches the nodes in the subtrees ofthe ancestor nodes by turn all the way to the
root. If no matching node is found, the function returns null.
comment.full:
Finds the first node with a given name that satisfies the given acceptor.
The serach algorithm works as follows: Nodes in the subtree are matched first, then
it matches the nodes in the subtrees ofthe ancestor nodes by turn all the way to the
root. If no matching node is found, the function returns null.

comment.brief: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.
comment.full: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.

comment.brief: If you override `OnRooted` you must call `base.OnRooted()` first in your derived class. No other processing should happen first, otherwise you might end up in an undefined state.
comment.full: If you override `OnRooted` you must call `base.OnRooted()` first in your derived class. No other processing should happen first, otherwise you might end up in an undefined state.

comment.brief: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.
comment.full: Returns the next sibling node of the given type.
